comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
From 1901: 
Mc Cabe, Cornelius, Broughton Street, Dundalk Urban No. 4.Louth, 61, M, Co Louth, Boot Maker, Roman Catholic, Read right, Head of Family, Married

I'd say that clinches it.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Courthouse is 1819 From archiseek.com/2010/1819-courthouse-dundalk-co-louth/#.UXo... Designed by Edward Park and supposedly based on the portico design and dimensions of the Temple of Theseus in Athens, Dundalk Courthouse is a fabulous classical revival building. Its main façade is dramatic, the absence of openings save for the entrance within the solidly imposing portico makes for a stern and forbidding face. The lack of any figurative sculpture of carving on the pediment only heightens the building’s wonderful starkness. Every Irish town should have a courthouse as fine as this one. So no help with dating

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The Burns mobile knife-sharpening empire appears to have disolved with the demise of its founder. There's no Burns with the profession of cutler in the 1901 census and none of the shopkeepers are anywhere near Dundalk.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/] There is an unexpected connection between Dundalk and the poet, Robert Burns though! www.irishidentity.com/extras/gaels/stories/burns.htm

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: No Burnses in Dundalk in 1837 either www.jbhall.freeservers.com/1837_dundalk_householders.htm

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I assumed from the mobile sharpenimijig that he was from Newry (which was crammed to bursting with Burnses in 1901) or some other local town. There's only 40 of them in the whole of Louth (none of them remotely connected with the slicing business), so I reckon he's from points north.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The Maid of Erin statue is not in our photo - anyone know when it was erected? See 193.178.1.203/econet/dldocument.aspx?id=239 Page 8

comment._content: It was erected 1899 so no help

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Reilly's hairdressers were still here come the 1901 census. By then he was 47, so unless he was the second generation of "Reilly's Hairdressers", I suspect we're closer to 1883 than the lower bound. (EDIT - Mixed marriage - Shocker! :) )

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
How was this moved around?
I remember a bloke in the 1940s with a mobile knife sharpener.
The big grindstone was mounted on a wooden wheelbarrow.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] perhaps he tips it over and uses the wheel :-)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] No mysteries as to how this knife-grinder moved his gear around.

comment.author: 40160780@N02
comment._content: I remember, when I was young in Dublin, a travelling knife-sharpener who turned an ordinary bicycle upside down: it had a spinning whetstone attached, operated by the pedals. Most of the other tradesmen, the coal-man, the laundry-man, the vegetable-man, the rag-and-bone man and the egg-man used horses and carts.

comment.author: 62379908@N00
